hints.content: Start by understanding what 'parity' means. Parity refers to whether a number is odd or even. An even number has a parity of 0, while an odd number has a parity of 1.
Consider the definition of a special array: adjacent elements must have different parity. This means if one element is even, the next must be odd, and vice versa.
Think about how you can check the parity of an integer. You can use the modulus operator: `num % 2`. If the result is 0, the number is even; if it’s 1, it’s odd.
To check pairs of adjacent elements, you will need to iterate through the array. Remember that you will need to compare each element with the one that follows it.
When iterating, keep in mind the array's bounds. You should stop before the last element to avoid going out of bounds when checking the next element.
Consider edge cases, such as when the array has only one element. Since there are no adjacent elements to compare, it should automatically return true.

As you iterate through the array, you can maintain a boolean variable to track whether the array is special. If you find any pair of adjacent elements with the same parity, you should set this variable to false.
Make sure to return the correct type. The function should return a boolean value: `true` for a special array and `false` otherwise.
Think about the time complexity of your solution. Since you will be iterating through the array once, your solution should run in O(n) time, where n is the length of the array.
Finally, put all these pieces together in your code. Loop through the array, check the parity of each adjacent pair, and return the result based on your findings.

questionNotes: The array is considered special if all adjacent pairs have different parity.
If the array has only one element, it is automatically considered special.
